technical.name: FuzzBot
technical.short: My first project: a multi-purpose Discord bot

technical.name: 2D-RPG
technical.short: A 2D Text-based RPG, with a very clever name

left:
**<2DRPG V1>**After my Ludum Dare 45 game, I concluded that for me, the best game I can make single-handedly is a game with next to no, or no graphics. Therefore, a text-adventure game would be the most likely bet, as it leverages my strengths: programming & writing.
I decided to set out with the same theme as my Ludum Dare Game: you see nothing. There are caveats in the game, making long-term continuation of it difficult, for the writing I did was highly unorganizd. However, through the writing, I figured out what this kind of game would need. I used LibGDX, a Java game framework, to build my own text-based game engine. This included text stages, towns, buildings, fights, and NPC encounters with a variety of possible options for each encounter. I held development on the game not due to limitations with the programming aspects, or creation of the game engine, but writing for long stretches for NPCs, scenarios, dungeons, and more became tedious.
Future forrays into games after this became more technical, my next substantial work being a contributor to OddFolk, a ASCII Open-world Rouge-like built in Java. Later, I would come back to this style of game, with a more organized approach.
https://youtu.be/SJjCnfRwcmE
right:
**<2DRPG V2>**I came back to this style of game after about a year of waiting. For OddFolk, having worked on a primative dialogue loading system in Java with my extra experience, I realized there were many more ways to create a dialogue system than the one I created for the first iteration of this game.
Instead of Java & LibGDX, Godot & GDScript were used to create a more polished feel, and an easier time creating and poritng the game to different platforms. A system in GDScript that would read .txt files and compile them into a game that could be played. As a result of this modularity, only a haldful of maybe 2-3 files of code are used, and only a few hundred lines, rather than the copy and paste amalgomation that was the previous iteration of this game.
This system is also far easier to use, making the only road-block in the creation of the game to be the writing aspect. However, I set forth on this game with an idea in mind, and although a vague idea, its an idea that Im fond of and would like to pursue further.

technical.name: TRPG Prototype
technical.short: A prototype for a game that was too ambitious

left:
****This un-named prototype is something I started working on at the end of sophomore year. Enfatuated with the idea of turn-based strategy games, I decided to go down a route taking inspiration from games such as Divinity Original Sin, Xcom, and Shadowrun.
This game would have used pixel art, primarily sprites that are 16x16, as art was not my primary focus. Through this I was able to learn pixel art more in depth, something that can be very useful in the game-dev world.
Furthermore, I learned a few things through this project such as A* pathfinding, and a deeper look into the Unity game engine. In this prototype I was able to include a map generator from png images (which I was planning on modifying in the future), random enemy spawning and clustering, A* pathfinding, game states, and many other minor features! The next step in this game would be to create AI logic for the enemies, as a system for AI already exists.
Throughout the process of game development, I recorded two videos detailing my progress, as well as did a live-stream where I did some pixel art.

technical.name: PiPlant
technical.short: First & last HS group project: A talking plant

left: **<Abstract>**From the Peddie Computer Science Club Website: The Raspberry Pi Talking plant is a plant monitoring system that allows for human-plant communication. It includes a web interface that allows users to monitor key statistics regarding their plant, including plant temperature, plant humidity, and air temperature. Also included are graphs that keep track of the data so that users can easily keep track of temperature and humidity growth over time. On the other hand of the project lies the “communication” side, where text-to-speech software is used to communicate with the users. Various python libraries are put together to have plants respond to user commands and questions based on keywords. With this project, we hope to be able to give plant caretakers more tools to aid their endeavors and to give everyone a new companion.
url>https://github.com/akalyan23/pyschic-plant-man(GitHub) url>https://trello.com/b/J3Io1G6m/raspberry-pi-plant-project(Trello)
right: **<Overview>** PiPlant was both my first and last group project in HighSchool. Done with Rohan Nunugonda '22 and Aditya Kalyan '23, work would be split among working on sensors for the plant, working on the back-end UNIX & Python implementation, and the front-end design and data processing. I worked on front-end and also a bit on handling/parsing commands on the back-end.
img>https://skymocha.net/Projects/PiPlant/assets/Desktop.jpg Front-End for the project inspired by Windows XP Background

technical.name: NS02
technical.short: A semi-sucessful experiment in wireless audio & audio visualization

left:
****My first term of Sophomore Year I was tasked with a open-ended project using a Raspberry Pi. The final result is a remote for a speaker. The program runs a Python (Flask) backend, connected to a web-page remote, containing a music visualizer, as well as a way to choose the currently playing song.
The remote is paired to a Raspberry Pi connected to a custom-built speaker, made of 2 sheets of Balsa wood, with Dayton Audio exciters connected in parallel.
The original intent of the project was to hook up LEDs to the piece of Balsa Wood, and CAD & Laser Print a mount for the speaker. The LEDs would light up as a music visualizer depending on the song being played, and the mount would be attatched to the wall and help for better audio. In the end, I did not get that far. I created a mount in CAD but never finalized and created it, and although I had a partial music visualizer in software, it was not good enough for LED hookup.
At the end of the term, I was asked to give a presentation on the project, which can be seen on the right.

technical.name: TARPG V1/V2

technical.name: 5895 Pit Screen
technical.short: An open source pit screen for FRC teams

left: **<Overview>** 5895 or Peddie Robotics is The Peddie School's FRC team. I participated my sophomore, junior, and senior years, however, due to the high stress of build season, I quit about four weeks in. url>FRC 5895 Website url>FRC 5895 Instagram

**<2020 Season>** 2020 was my frist FIRST season. Our build season was uninterupted by COVID, and although we consistently fell behind schedule, we produced one of our districts best robots.
As no one on the team was familiar with wiring and pneumatics, our mentor Mr. Meredith taught me the ropes, and I was the person most in charge of wiring the robot electrically and pneumatically. During our first competition I was on call in case the wiring broke, but it never did.
We won our first competion, almost guarenteeing us a trip to district championships, and possibly even world championships in Detroit.
Sadly, due to COVID, none of this happened.
img>http://frc5895.peddie.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/e8SVSmFh-448x448.jpg 2020 Robot: Emperor Goose
right: **<2021 Season>** The 2021 season was lackluster due to COVID. Our team was split across the world, so those of us who were at Peddie worked on creating a simple swerve bot. This season was mostly just to train new people, and also keep older poeple from losing their learned experience. We also worked on a few off-season projects, such as event-day gear & organization. I taught some of the new students wiring, and also began learning how to drive Emperor Goose for fun.

**<2022 Season>** Although I quit four weeks into build season for 2022, I contributed greatly to the team by helping prototype and design the shooter for our robot. After getting a rough prototype design for the flywheel shooter, me and my subteam spent hours shooting with different wheels, angles, etc. My job was to take note of all the different inputs and find out what the best shooter angles and wheel materials were for the balls used in 2022. Thanks to my work, the subsequent work of other students, and the programming team we had one of the best shooters in our district and made it to world championships in Houston.

technical.name: nPoser
technical.short: Data Processor for Music Generation AI

left:
****Over the summer between Freshmen and Sophomore year, I decided to look into AI. For my beginner project after MNIST, I would create a msuic generation program. The first step, and ultimately my last, would be to convert audio into an image format. In the end, a MIDI file would be converted to a CSV file, which would therefore be converted into a image displaying the data of the CSV. The image could then be reverse-engineered back into a MIDI file, with minor flaws.
The flaw with this approach, however, is that songs would range between a few hundred lines and a few thousand lines. Not only is the variablity tough for AI to handle, but for longer songs, the amount of inputs would exceed anything that could compute them at my disposal. In the end, it was a scraped project, yet served as my first forray into data science rather than Artificial Intelligence.
right: img>https://skymocha.net/Projects/nickPosr/assets/Still%20More%20Fighting.png 'Still More Fighting' (Final Fantasy) turned from CSV to image format

technical.name: Caves of QUwUD
technical.short: A mod for the game Caves of Qud using Harmony & Data Science

left: **<Overview>** Caves of Qud is a text-heavy Unity engine game, and that text is serious, well-crafted, and intelligent. I decided I'd counteract all three by making all text UwU speech.

**** Caves of Qud's text falls into two categories of generation: Python & C#/Harmony.
Python: All quests, NPC interactions, and a few other things are all pre-determined through XML files in the games data. To make them UwU text, the easiest way of doing so would be to write a Python script that would turn all XML files text (not the tags or important information) into UwU text. The only down-side to this, and the only thing I would correct in the future, is that these XML files are core to the game. Therefore, when the game is updated with any form of changes to the XML, the mod will break. So, the currently existing mod only works for one version of the game.
C#/Harmony: All other text, such as message logs, are constructed within the code of the game. There is no 'pre-determined' way of changing the text, so it has to be changed during run-time in the C# code. The issue with this, though, is during run-time, methods cannot be directly modified. The way modders and the way I got around this is by using a library called Harmony. Harmony allows the modder to create prefixes / suffixes for methods, meaning that code can be executed before or after the methods initial code. So, say a method called addLog(Message) adds to the message log in Caves of Qud using a variable called Message. All I have to do as the modder is modify the Message variable into UwU text by adding a prefix to the addLog(Message) method. This way, by the time the actual addLog code is executed, Message is already UwU text.
right: **<Updates>** The major issue with the initial version of this project is that, because the Python scripts run locally on my computer and then the updated versions are uploaded to the mod page, after one CoQ update that changes any of the XML files, the mod completely breaks. As a result, new versions of those mod would either have to run the Python script to compile new XML files at run-time or run all text through the C#/Harmony patches.

left:
**** After missing the opportunity to compete in my second Ludum Dare, I decided the next best thing would be to record myself competing in MiniJam, a bi-weekly game jam.
My project would be a simple game where you move around in a small solar system. After making my first planet based on Earth, I found that one of the continents looked very much like an avocado, so I decided to name the planet Avocado. After that, I began naming and also designing my planets around certain foods.
This project was extremely insightful for me. Although it did not involve much programming, I did do all the artwork. The artwork was simple pixel art, yet, art ended up being my highest rating in the jam. Pixel art, when given character and emotion can carry a project or game.

**** 'Odd Folk is a Roguelike survival simulation hybrid.'
OddFolk was a project I found on r/RogueLikeDev back in 2020 while looking for open source projects to contribute to. The project was claiming to be an ASCII open-world rogue-like and I was incredibly interested in helping out. I contacted the lead developers at Lockhead.nl, a small indie game developer of, if memory serves, two or three people to see where I could help out. Lockhead.nl is no longer a functioning URL and I have had trouble finding OddFolk online.
After joining the project's Discord, I helped out by making a few commits to the UI of the game. The game's UI system was incredibly broken and looked horrendous, so I cleaned it up, added new features such as co-ordinates, and improved the functionality of the UI.
After I finished up some of my work on the UI, I began working on a text parser/proccessor for NPC dialogue. This would inspire some of my own future prototypes for games such as 2DRPG that use text parsers to create most of their games. It even inspired this portfolio, as it runs off one single .json file wrapped around by a React.JS app!

technical.name: Discord Quiz
technical.short: A simple NPM package built on Discord.JS

left: **<Overview>** In trying to remake one of my YouTube tutorials on quiz commands within Discord.JS, I decided it would be easiest to create a NPM package built ontop of Discord.JS and then create a tutorial around that. The package has since recieved 5,000 downloads on NPM and one or two off-hand updates updating it to the latest versions of Discord.JS
url>https://www.npmjs.com/package/discord-quiz(NPM Page) url>https://github.com/SkyMocha/DiscordQuiz(GitHub)

nontechnical.name: Why The Trans Programmer?
nontechnical.short: Do Trans Women Disproportionately Go Into Computer Science?

left:
****This project consists of three questions explored over a months-long time-period. It consists of a primary video essay, followed a few months later by a well-researched paper, and finally by a follow-up video essay covering the topic in the most depth.
Questions:
1. Do Trans Women Disproportionately Go Into CS?
2. Why Do Trans Women Disproportionately Go Into CS?
3. So, Why Don't Cis Women?

**<Original Video>**The orginal video for 'Why The Trans Programmer?' was primarily focused on annecdotal evidence from what I saw occuring in the world and what others did. As a result it ws more of a loosely bullet-pointed vlog with minimal citations. The follow-up-video wuld be a far better-researched video with a paper component archived to IEEE Xplore (currently available through ArXiV).
https://youtu.be/mumIp8tFmcA
right: **<Paper Abstract>** Through online anecdotal evidence and online communities, there is an in-group idea of trans people (specifically trans-feminine individuals) disproportionately entering computer science education & fields. Existing data suggests this is a plausible trend, yet no research has been done into exactly why. As computer science education (traditional schooling or self-taught methods) is integral to working in computer science fields, a simple research survey was conducted to gather data on 138 trans people’s experiences with computer science & computer science education. This article’s purpose is to shed insight on the motivations for trans individuals choosing computer science paths, while acting as a basis and call to action for further research.

nontechnical.name: Geiger Reeves Speaking Contest
nontechnical.short: A shcool scpeech competition; wining hearts and awards

left: **<Overview>** The Peddie School has two yearly speech competetions, a monologue competition (The Declemation), and a written speech competition (Geiger Reeves). I participated three times: Fresmen, Junior, & Senior Years. The Geiger Reeves Speaking Contest, alongside my time in Speech & Debate at Peddie has been integral to my growth as an actor.

**** For my innagural entry into the speech competition, I already knew most people would look deep within themselves and find some meaningfull topic to convey to an audiance whether to win the competition, or to spread a message. I took this opportunity to be more light-hearted, humorous, yet still impactful and sincere: I wrote about my love life. Although I won nothing for this speech, I recieving weeks of congratulations alongside the only standing ovation.
Video unavailable due to the video being pre-transition. Audio TBD.

****My junior year I strived for a balance of light-heartnedness and an importantance. As a result, I talked about something that many high-school students struggle with: being considered 'weird.' The speech centered around celebrating weirdness.
Due to COVID the speeches were not delivered on stage, but recorded in video. For this speech I recieved honorable mention out of approx. 30 competitors.
right: **<Senior Reeevs: Leave Us Alone>** For my final Reeeves speech, I decided to work on a more serious topic and delivery. Although I am good at comededy, delivering a serious and impassioned speech is something I still struggled with at the time. I went with somewhat recent topics: The BBCs treatment of trans people. The speech centered on my experiences as a trans person with both my identity and with this particular topic. I won honorable mention and posted the preformance to my YouTube channel.

nontechnical.name: Fight Club's Incel To Exploitable Chad Pipeline
nontechnical.short: A feature film YouTube video on Fight Club, Incels, & Trump

left: **<Overview>**A self-led project, with initial advising from Dr. Ami Shah of the Peddie School’s English department, with contributions from Abriana Fergesun, Reed Turner, Doran Penner, and Eli McKinzie. Started as my high-school senior thesis, this project explores Fight Club: the movie by David Fincher and the book by Chuck Phalanick; dissecting it, then using it as a lens of analysis for the 2016 presidential campaign of Donald Trump, primarily focusing on the aspects of micro-targeting incels and other manosphere communities by Cambridge Analytica outlined in the memoir Mindf*ck by Christopher Wylie. Through drawing parallels between fiction and the real world, conclusions can be made about the populist rhetoric and ideology used by both Tyler Durden in Fight Club and by Donald Trump.
right: Video is a WIP & currently in recording & editing phase

left: **<Overview>** PeddieHacks is a yearly hackathon hosted by The Peddie School. The Hackathon started shortly before COVID, so for its first two years it has been online.

**** During the 2019-2020 school year, my schools Computer Science club began planning an in-person Hackathon; held in our schools science center, we would invite all participants from the surrounding schools to gether on these two floors to create. However, amidst a global pandemic, we decided to make it an online Hackathon from August 22nd to August 23rd, 2020. The Hackathon was primarily hosted over Discord, where I was a communicator, as well as administrator and organizer.
Day one was primarily the opening, and things went smoothly as it was primarily the opening ceremony and brainstorming for teams; however, as the end approached on day two things got hectic very quickly leading to a 15 hour work day. During the second day I was tasked at the start (9 AM) to lead a game session, and later throughout the day was tasked on things such as checking in with teams, creating a judging schedule, making announcements, and more. The greatest challenge was organizing the judging; as judging was supposed to be approximately 3 to 4 hours, but ended up lasting almost 7 full hours. I was for the majority of those 7 hours constantly adjusting the schedule to accomodate teams and help judges.
In the end I only survived thanks to lots of caffeine.
img>https://skymocha.net/Projects/PeddieHacks/assets/PHacks_Judging_Schedule.jpg PeddieHacks 2020 Judging Schedule: Built with black magic, caffeine, sleep deprevation, and hard work.
right:
**** For 2021 Peddie Hacks, I took a more backseat approach to the organization. After the hell that was 2020, I wanted a more relaxing experience. However, I did serve during the orginazation process by making suggestions by attending the organization zoom meetings. Most of my suggestions served to help create the judging criteria.
During the actual competition, my biggest roles were once again being the MC and organizing the Discord server. I updated the 2020 PeddieHacks Discord bot, documented it, and put it on GitHub for future students to use. This was vital in organizing teams, giving them rooms to work, and checking in with them.
When it came to being master of ceremonies, I ran the latter half of the opening cermonies, and the entire closing cermonies. I definitiely did not do my best during the closing ceremonies. I was given the slides three minutes before go time, so I made a lot of mistakes, but cold reading is my specialty.

**<PeddieHacks 2022>** For the 2022 hackathon, I choose to keep contributions to the project minimal, as my summer was primarily geared towards getting ready for college. I did a few bits of maintenance on the Peddie Hacks Discord bot, but that was more or less the extent of what I did.

url>https://www.peddie.org/about-us/stories/stories-detail/~board/news/post/peddiehacks-challenges-participants-to-code-a-better-world(Peddie Hacks 2021 Blog Post) url>https://peddiehacks.peddie.org/(Peddie Hacks Website) url>https://github.com/SkyMocha/PeddieHacks_Bot(Peddie Hacks Discord Bot)
